Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Situating the Effects of Public US Environmental Policy Making

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Government regulations that shape our lives are often influenced by a legal procedure known as "informal rulemaking," or "notice and comment." This procedure allows members of the public to submit comments critiquing policies before they become law. Its effectiveness in terms of participation in governance hinges on what happens to comments once they are submitted. This research project investigates the way bureaucratic actors construct and respond to perceptions of "the public" in rule-creation and rule-implementation, specifically around environmental governance. How do government officials interpret commenters' ideas of what the environment is and how it is valued? And how do government officials, who have their own experiences and beliefs, create the details of this legal process through behaviors and social practices carried out in their day-to-day work lives?

The research plan involves 13 months on site in the Environmental Protection Agency, including agency approved participant observation and interviews with its employees. In addition, the researcher will conduct interviews with commenters and analyze their submissions to learn how they experience and value the environment and participation in informal rulemaking. This research will contribute to understanding of both how government officials' everyday work justifies policy decisions about how to implement public participation mechanisms and the effects on state-making of officials' notions of citizenship, governance, and public participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award covered approximately 15 months of ethnographic fieldwork on environmental policymaking in the United States. Most federal regulations are required by law to undergo a comment period before they are finalized, allowing the public to offer input on the proposed regulation. This project asked both how "notice and comment rulemaking" is created through the behaviors and social practices of the federal civil servants who undertake it, and how such government employees interpreted commenters' narratives of what the environment is and how they value it. The data collected during this research documented the social practices that accompany environmental policymaking as civil servants work through multiple considerations, including input from various categories of "the public." The research built a foundation for further data collection, to be undertaken from 1/2019-5/2019, on how commenters interacted with notice and comment rulemaking to better understand how the law matters differently to different actors. Further analysis of fieldwork data will address how government employees create, reinforce, and push back on boundaries of the state.


The fieldwork was conducted by Chandra L. Middleton, under the supervision of Dr. Bill Maurer (University of California, Irvine). The co-PI collected data through several methods, including: participant-observation as an intern at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; participating in lifescapes of Washington, DC; and conducting approximately 30 semi-structured interviews with former and current government employees, contractors, and interns with the EPA and other federal agencies that undertake notice and comment rulemaking. Data collected includes: everyday life as a federal civil servant; legal, political, and social interpretations of legal mechanisms; social practices within and beyond the EPA; and insight into civil servants' work and workplaces. Data was also collected to identify individual commenters; surveys, interviews, and focus groups with these individuals are ongoing.


The research uncovered how civil servants manage some of the hidden constraints they face in the process of rulemaking, including incorporating various types of expertise, sorting and analyzing public comments, and writing the preamble text to proposed rules, which often provides the frame for interpretation of rule text. The research revealed the social and textual complexity of rulemaking, and spotlights the importance of administrative law to governance in the United States. It also documents important insight into the ways in which "the state" operates, bringing into focus the multiple state interests that are represented by multiple agencies, government employees, knowledge bases, and legal processes as environmental regulations are created. This project's focus on relocating legal and administrative processes as products of human social relations will potentially offer the public a deeper understanding of how policy is made, possibly effecting new ways for advocates to interact with the people, legal mechanisms, and political processes that create federal policy.
